Composting 101: What, Why, and How?

Composting is a process of breaking down organic materials into nutrient-rich soil. It’s an excellent way to reduce waste and provide natural fertilizer for your garden. In this post, we’ll cover the basics of composting – what it is, why it’s important, and how to get started.

What is Composting?

Composting is a natural process that occurs when microorganisms break down organic matter such as food scraps, yard waste, and paper products. The result is a rich soil amendment called compost that can be used in gardening or landscaping.

The key to successful composting lies in creating the right conditions for the microorganisms to thrive. This includes balancing carbon-rich materials (such as dried leaves) with nitrogen-rich materials (such as fruit and vegetable scraps), maintaining adequate moisture levels, and providing oxygen through regular turning or mixing.

Why Compost?

There are many reasons why composting is beneficial:

  • Reduced Waste: By diverting organic material from landfills, you can significantly reduce your household waste.
  • Natural Fertilizer: Compost provides essential nutrients for plants while improving soil structure and water retention.
  • Cost Savings: Rather than purchasing expensive fertilizers or soil amendments, you can create your own using kitchen scraps and yard waste.
  • Sustainable Living: Composting supports sustainable living by reducing greenhouse gas emissions associated with landfill disposal while also promoting healthy soils for future generations.

How to Start Composting

If you’re ready to start composting at home, here are some simple steps to get started:

Step 1: Choose a Composting Method

There are several different methods for composting, including traditional bin systems, tumblers, and vermicomposting (using worms). Consider your space, time, and budget when selecting a method.

Step 2: Gather Materials

You’ll need a balance of carbon-rich “browns” and nitrogen-rich “greens.” Browns include dried leaves, straw, and paper products while greens include fruit/vegetable scraps and grass clippings. You can also add soil or finished compost to introduce microorganisms.

Step 3: Build Your Pile or Bin

If using a bin system, follow the manufacturer’s instructions. If creating an open pile in your yard, start with a layer of browns followed by greens. Continue layering until you have a pile that is roughly three feet tall.

Step 4: Maintain Your Compost

Aerate your compost regularly by turning or mixing it every few days. Keep it moist but not too wet – aim for the consistency of a wrung-out sponge. In 6-12 months (depending on conditions), you should have finished compost!

The Bottom Line

Composting is an easy way to reduce waste while creating natural fertilizer for your garden. By following these simple steps, you’ll be well on your way to successful composting!
